text:
Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from English with 
Jennifer. It's nice to study with you again,

and in this lesson, I plan 
to share some very good tips.

Let me try that again. It's a true delight to 
study with you again, and in this lesson, I plan

to share some highly useful tips. Practical tips. 
Valuable tips. Well, you get the point. Let's

talk about ways we can avoid overused words like 
"nice" and "good." Time to boost your vocabulary.

"Good' is not a bad word. 
No one can argue otherwise.

However, we tend to overuse it when we 
could make the effort to be more accurate.

Consider these alternatives. The 
weather's been pleasant. Can't complain.

She's a diligent student, a hard-working 
student, a talented student,
a student with a lot of potential.

He's a dedicated employee, a loyal employee, a 
highly-skilled staff member, a competent worker.

Can you come up with alternatives 
for these phrases? Take a look.
I'll help. Choose from these words.

I'd say a wise decision, a clear 
plan, a valuable opportunity.

"Bad" is naturally bad, but 
could we be more precise?
What other words can we use in these phrases?
Again, let me help. Choose from these words.
I'd say poor judgment, weak grammar, ill timing.

Partly, I'm being influenced by 
collocations, common word combinations.

We could also say "poor grammar," "poor 
timing." I wouldn't say "ill grammar," though.

"Ill timing" is a collocation. It's a common 
combination of words. You can learn collocations

by giving yourself regular exposure to natural 
English. Listen to podcasts, watch movies,

read news articles and books on subjects you find 
interesting. Pay attention to how words are used.

Okay. Let's talk about nice things. 
It's surely nice to get a compliment,

isn't it? When people say something nice, 
we should say, "Thank you." They can say,

"You have a nice smile. A nice voice. You do nice 
work." It all feels nice to hear, doesn't it?

But imagine how much more precious a 
compliment can be if you choose more precise,

more colorful words. And imagine how 
much more helpful your feedback could be

if you focus on what exactly someone is doing 
well. So, let's try to rewrite these statements.

Any ideas? Here are mine. That was a strong 
presentation. It was clear and informative.
That was incredibly helpful. Thank you.
I have friendly neighbors. They always say hi.

Peter does quality work, and he's 
consistent. He gives attention to detail.

Let's practice replacing 
"good," "bad," and "nice."

Here are my matches: a solid foundation, a 
disappointing performance, a refreshing change,
sloppy handwriting,
a secure job.

What are some other overused words? 
"Very" is one, along with "really."

Have you seen my lesson on intensifiers? 
I'll put the link in the video description.

Right now, replace "really" 
and "very" in these sentences.

You can say, "They have an incredibly 
beautiful home, an absolutely beautiful home."

And we could say, "He's terribly 
lonely. He's awfully lonely.

And actually "beautiful" is another word we 
can often replace. What are some alternatives?
a gorgeous sunset
a stunning dress
a dazzling smile
an elegant restaurant
a magnificent voice

Can you describe this photo 
without using the word "beautiful"?

Since we're talking about overused words, 
I should mention overused structures,

ones that sound rather flat. If you want 
your English, particularly your writing,

to sound more dynamic, I suggest 
limiting your use of "there

is/there are." Look at these statements. 
Let's consider how we can reword them.
There are too many people in the city.

The city is crowded. The city is 
overcrowded. It's overflowing with people.
There is a need for change.

We need change. It's time 
for change. Change is needed.
Can you reword these sentences?

Here are my suggestions. Some chairs were blocking 
the door. The door was blocked by some chairs.
Some chairs stood in the way.

More severe weather is expected. We 
can expect to see more severe weather.
More severe weather is on its way.

Here a few more words you can try to avoid. Do you 
say "great" too much? Consider these alternatives.
Wonderful. Amazing. Fabulous.

Find a different way to tell 
me you had a great time.

Did you think of one? How about using 
an idiom? You can say, "I had a blast."
That means, "I had fun."

Do you need alternatives to 
"important"? Study these phrases.
a significant change
a life-changing decision, a crucial step
a valuable tip
a critical point in a process

Find a different way to say that you have 
something important to tell me right away.

Can you think of an alternative? 
How about just saying it's urgent?
How about some alternatives to "happy"?

If you're happy with a product or a service, 
say that you're satisfied or pleased.

If you're happy to receive an 
opportunity, say you're thrilled.
That's a mixture of happiness and excitement.

Let's consider other alternatives other synonyms 
for "happy." Where do these synonyms work best?

Here's how I'd replace the 
word "happy" in each sentence.

I was so relieved to hear the news. 
Thank goodness everything is okay.
They were delighted to be invited.
The new parents were overjoyed.
Children's movies use upbeat music.

Note that it's okay to use all the 
words we talked about in this lesson.

Just try not to overuse them. In some 
cases, these words are very natural

and expected. Everyday wishes include, 
"Have a nice day! Have a good time!

Happy birthday!" And everyday greetings 
use "good." "Good morning! Good evening."

Sincere compliments are always welcome, even 
with commonly used words: Great job! Nice work.

Not bad! Not bad at all. You did really 
well. You look great! You look beautiful.

But when you find yourself using 
the same words a bit too often,

especially in your writing, challenge yourself 
to express your ideas more accurately.

Hopefully, you now have ways to avoid these 
overused words. Make the effort to be more

accurate, more precise, more colorful, 
and more dynamic with your word choices.

Let's end here. I think I gave you enough to think 
about for now. Please remember to like and share

the video if you found the lesson useful. As 
always, thanks for watching and happy studies!

Hey everyone! Did you know that you can become 
a member of my channel? Click the JOIN button.

You'll get written practice tasks twice a week 
on the community tab. You also get access to a

member only playlist and my audio GIFs on Emojam. 
Every time you comment on my channel, you'll have

a special badge next to your name. So, go ahead 
and click JOIN. It's only one dollar a month.

It's an easy way to get extra practice and 
support my channel. Follow me on Facebook,

Twitter, and Instagram. Why not join me on 
Patreon? And don't forget to subscribe on YouTube.
